headline.main: Brock Adams Quits Senate Race Amid Sex Misconduct Allegations

results.snippet: Senator Brock Adams of Washington gave up his campaign for a second term today after a newspaper quoted eight unidentified women who accused him of sexual misconduct over a period of years.   Denying the accusations at an emotional news conference...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator Brock Adams of Washington gave up his campaign for a second term today after a newspaper quoted eight unidentified women who accused him of sexual misconduct over a period of years. Denying the accusations at an emotional news conference here, the 65-year-old Senator, a liberal Democrat who was Secretary of Transportation under President Jimmy Carter, said his decision to drop out of the race was "not an admission of anything." And he urged the press to "begin to police yourselves."

results.snippet: An article yesterday about Senator Brock Adams's announcement that he would not seek re-election referred incorrectly in some copies to his response to allegations of inappropriate sexual advances. Mr. Adams said the accusations were "absolutely...
results.lead_paragraph: An article yesterday about Senator Brock Adams's announcement that he would not seek re-election referred incorrectly in some copies to his response to allegations of inappropriate sexual advances. Mr. Adams said the accusations were "absolutely false." In some copies, the article also misstated the background of Washington's other Senator, Slade Gorton. He is not a former astronaut.

headline.main: Fresh Air for the Space Agency

results.snippet: The Bush Administration has chosen a little-known aerospace executive to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration -- to the surprise and alarm of old space hands and many Congressmen. But from the evidence at hand, Daniel Goldin,...
results.lead_paragraph: The Bush Administration has chosen a little-known aerospace executive to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration -- to the surprise and alarm of old space hands and many Congressmen. But from the evidence at hand, Daniel Goldin, general manager of TRW's Space and Technology Group, appears a reasonable choice to lead the beleaguered space agency at this critical juncture. Mr. Goldin, who must be confirmed by the Senate, would succeed Adm. Richard Truly, who was forced to retire because of friction between the agency and the National Space Council, headed by Vice President Quayle.

headline.main: Space Council Cuts NASA's Role In Exploration of Moon and Mars

results.snippet: The National Space Council tightened its control over space activities today by dividing NASA's responsibility for the Moon-Mars project among several Government agencies.   Vice President Dan Quayle, who heads the space council, made public a...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Space Council tightened its control over space activities today by dividing NASA's responsibility for the Moon-Mars project among several Government agencies. Vice President Dan Quayle, who heads the space council, made public a space policy directive approved by President Bush that assigns "major roles" to the Department of Defense and the Department of Energy while establishing the National Aeronautics and Space Administration as the principal agency in the project.

results.snippet: The first space mission of the post-Soviet era blasted off today with an international crew carrying hopes of rejuvenating the troubled space program of the Commonwealth of Independent States.   A German and two Russian astronauts thundered into a...
results.lead_paragraph: The first space mission of the post-Soviet era blasted off today with an international crew carrying hopes of rejuvenating the troubled space program of the Commonwealth of Independent States. A German and two Russian astronauts thundered into a blue sky aboard a 160-foot Soyuz TM-14 rocket on their way to a rendezvous on Thursday with the Mir space station orbiting 200 miles above Earth.

headline.main: For Two (Ex-Soviet) Astronauts, an Alien World Lies Ahead

results.snippet: Rip Van Winkle had it easy. After a long sleep, he had to contend with a new nation, new fashions and new friends. But at least his village had the same name. And there was plenty of food and drink to go around. And he knew where he stood socially....
results.lead_paragraph: Rip Van Winkle had it easy. After a long sleep, he had to contend with a new nation, new fashions and new friends. But at least his village had the same name. And there was plenty of food and drink to go around. And he knew where he stood socially. Things could be tougher for two astronauts scheduled to return to Earth today.

headline.main: Shuttle Lifts Off to Study Atmosphere

results.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis thundered into orbit today, carrying an array of scientific instruments to conduct atmospheric studies that could influence major policy decisions for protecting the global environment.   After a one-day delay caused by...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Atlantis thundered into orbit today, carrying an array of scientific instruments to conduct atmospheric studies that could influence major policy decisions for protecting the global environment. After a one-day delay caused by fuel leaks, the Atlantis was launched on its planned eight-day mission at 8:14 A.M. Within hours, the seven astronauts were settled into orbit and busy preparing the 12 instruments for round-the-clock observations of the chemistry and physics of the upper atmosphere.

headline.main: The Crew of the Atlantis: 7 in the 46th Shuttle Flight

results.snippet: Charles F. Bolden Jr., Mission Commander   Colonel Bolden, 45 years old, is a Marine Corps pilot who is making his third shuttle flight. He has been an astronaut since 1980.   He was born in Columbia, S.C., and received a bachelor's degree in...
results.lead_paragraph: Charles F. Bolden Jr., Mission Commander Colonel Bolden, 45 years old, is a Marine Corps pilot who is making his third shuttle flight. He has been an astronaut since 1980. He was born in Columbia, S.C., and received a bachelor's degree in electrical science from the United States Naval Academy in 1968. He became a pilot in 1970 and flew more than 100 sorties in Vietnam. In 1978 he received a master's degree in systems management from the University of Southern California.

headline.main: Astronauts on Space Shuttle Test A Device to Study the Atmosphere

results.snippet: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle today tested an electron-beam gun that will be used to create artificial auroras over the Southern Hemisphere and low-frequency radio waves.   Tens of thousands of students worldwide equipped with special...
results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle today tested an electron-beam gun that will be used to create artificial auroras over the Southern Hemisphere and low-frequency radio waves. Tens of thousands of students worldwide equipped with special receivers will spend the next week listening for those waves.

headline.main: After 313 Days in Space, It's a Trip to a New World

results.snippet: Sergei Krikalev returned to Earth today five months later than originally planned, and might well wonder whether he landed on the right planet.    The Kazakhstan plains where he came down looked right. But the Soviet state whose seal still...
results.lead_paragraph: Sergei Krikalev returned to Earth today five months later than originally planned, and might well wonder whether he landed on the right planet. The Kazakhstan plains where he came down looked right. But the Soviet state whose seal still decorated his spacesuit was gone, and his home city of Leningrad was off the maps.

headline.main: Blown Fuse Aboard Space Shuttle Abruptly Ends Telescope's Mission

results.snippet: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis today lost a second scientific instrument to a blown fuse, this time a telescope that had been probing galaxies millions of light-years away.   The ultraviolet telescope was beaming back data on a...
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis today lost a second scientific instrument to a blown fuse, this time a telescope that had been probing galaxies millions of light-years away. The ultraviolet telescope was beaming back data on a cluster of galaxies in the direction of constellation Coma Berenices when it stopped working. Ground controllers spent hours trying to get the telescope back up and eventually concluded that it was hopeless.
